cmd.cites.cmd.second.line.cite: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information § 3:14

prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: The Australian decision of Talbot v. General Television Corporation Pty. Ltd.[1] dealt with a situation where a film producer developed an idea for a television series, and submitted the proposal to the defendants for review. Subsequently, the defendants made use of the idea, claiming it as their own. The issue in the case was whether the idea was sufficiently developed to constitute confidential information. The court concluded as follows:

The real problem … was to decide whether the idea, or concept, had been sufficiently developed, whether it had been developed to the point of setting out a format in which it could be presented, so that it was apparent that the concept could be carried into effect … Without deciding that it is always necessary for a plaintiff to go that far, I am satisfied that where a concept or idea has been developed to the stage where the plaintiff had developed his concept, it is capable of being the subject of a confidential communication. The plaintiff had developed his concept so that it would be seen to be a concept which had at least some attractiveness as a television program and to be something which was capable of being realized as an actuality.[2]

In a subsequent case of the English Court of Appeal, Fraser v. Thames Television Ltd.,[3] the court found that the Talbot decision, while not binding, was “of great assistance”. Fraser also held that even a well-known concept, if given a significant twist, can be worthy of protection:

I accept that to be capable of protection the idea must be sufficiently developed, so that it would be seen to be a concept which has at least some attractiveness for a television programme and which is capable of being realised as an actuality (see per Harris J in Talbot's case [1981] RPC 1 at 9). But I do not think this requirement necessitates in every case a full synopsis. In some cases the nature of the idea may require extensive development … in order to meet the criteria. But in others the criteria may be met by a short unelaborated statement of an idea. In Talbot's case itself I do not think the detailed submission … added very much of substance to the idea which is set out in one sentence …

Unquestionably, of course, the idea must have some significant element of originality not already in the realm of public knowledge. The originality may consist in a significant twist or slant to a well-known concept (see Talbot's case). This is, I think, by analogy, consistent with the statements in Saltman's case and Coco's case that novelty in the industrial field can be derived from the application of human ingenuity to well-known concepts.[4]

The leading case of Seager v. Copydex Ltd.[5] also supports the notion that an idea that is comparatively undeveloped is still capable of protection. In Seager, the plaintiff orally volunteered “the germ of the idea” for a different form of carpet grip. At the time, the defendants were not interested in developing the idea. Subsequently, the defendants were held liable for breach of confidence when they used the idea as a “springboard” to develop a new kind of carpet grip.[6] The courts will critically examine situations where it appears that a party has obtained a benefit through the use of another's resources without investing the necessary time and effort themselves.[7]
Talbot v. General Television Corporation Pty. Ltd., [1981] R.P.C. 1 (S.C. Vict.).

Talbot v. General Television Corporation Pty. Ltd., [1981] R.P.C. 1 (S.C. Vict.), at p. 9 (emphasis added). See also Pastor v. Chen (2002), 19 C.P.R. (4th) 206 (B.C. Prov. Ct.), wherein dance moves were considered to be protectable confidential information. To the contrary, see VS Visual Statement Inc. v. Insurance Corp. of British Columbia, 2003 CarswellBC 2648, 2003 BCSC 1610.
Fraser v. Thames Television Ltd., [1983] 2 All E.R. 101 (Q.B.).

Fraser v. Thames Television Ltd., [1983] 2 All E.R. 101 (Q.B.), at p. 121 (emphasis added). See also ICAM Technologies Corp. v. Ebco Industries Ltd. (1991), 6 B.L.R. (2d) 98, 36 C.P.R. (3d) 504 (B.C.S.C.), affd [1994] 3 W.W.R. 419, 85 B.C.L.R. (2d) 318 (C.A.); Pharand Ski Corp. v. Alberta (1991), 116 A.R. 326, 80 Alta. L.R. (2d) 216 (Q.B.), supp. reasons 122 A.R. 81, 81 Alta. L.R. (2d) 304 (Q.B.), supp. reasons [1992] 1 W.W.R. 501, 122 A.R. 395 (Q.B.). The information needs to be completely new: see Fairchild Engine & Airplane Corp. v. Cox, 50 N.Y.S.2d 643, 657 (N.Y. Sup. Ct. 1944).

The springboard doctrine has been applied in a number of Canadian cases: see, for example, Computer Workshops Ltd. v. Banner Capital Market Brokers Ltd. (1988), 50 D.L.R. (4th) 118 at pp. 131 and 135, 64 O.R. (2d) 266 (H.C.J.), affd 74 D.L.R. (4th) 767, 1 O.R. (3d) 398n (C.A.). In Omega Digital Data v. Airos Technology Inc. (1996), 32 O.R. (3d) 21 (Gen. Div.), the plaintiff was successful where the defendants had used information generated by the independent efforts of the plaintiff as a springboard. See also, McCormick Delisle & Thompson Inc. v. Ballantyne (2001), 145 O.A.C. 379, 12 B.L.R. (3d) 257 (C.A.), leave to appeal to S.C.C refused 158 O.A.C. 196n, 285 N.R. 397n.

See also Cadbury Schweppes Inc. v. FBI Foods Ltd., [1999] 1 S.C.R. 142, 167 D.L.R. (4th) 577, and Terrapin Ltd. v. Builder's Supply Co. (Hayes) Ltd., [1967] R.P.C. 375 (Ch.). See for example, Sheehan and Rosie Ltd. v. Northwood, 2000 C.L.L.C. ¶ 210-037, [2000] O.J. No. 716 (S.C.J.); GasTOPS Ltd. v. Forsyth (2009), 181 A.C.W.S. (3d) 484, 2009 CanLII 66153 (Ont. S.C.J.); Apotex Fermentation Inc. v. Novopharm Ltd. (1998), 162 D.L.R. (4th) 111, [1998] 10 W.W.R. 455 (Man. C.A.); Pat's Off-Road Transport v. Campbell (2010), 191 A.C.W.S. (3d) 236, 2010 ABQB 443; Stonetile (Canada) Ltd. v. Castcon Ltd. (2010), 84 C.P.R. (4th) 350, 2010 ABQB 392.
